title: Obese 20-stone nurse ashamed of telling patients to eat healthy sheds HALF her body weight after simple diet change
text:
Katie in size 2X scrubs before she had her gastric sleeve surgery (Photo: PA Real Life) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A 20-stone nurse shed half her body weight in a bid to inspire overweight patients to slim. 
Katie Burgauer’s love of stodgy carbohydrate-heavy foods such as pasta and potatoes saw her pile on the pounds. 
Between the ages of 21 and 24, she shot up from a size large to a XXL. 
Now 26, Katie became used to hiding under baggy clothes and had to order XXL scrubs for work. 
But when she started her job as a hospital nurse in September 2013, she saw firsthand how weight is linked to conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure and heart disease. Katie's new slim figure (Photo: PA Real Life) The nurse had an operation to remove the excess skin she was left with after her dramatic weight loss (Photo: PA Real Life) Read More The 7 diet myths busted to help you lose weight and keep it off for good 
Frightened of what problems her fat would cause her in later life, and feeling hypocritical when talking to patients about healthy eating and exercise, she decided it was time to take her own advice. 
Now, Katie – who at her heaviest weighed 20 stone and wore a size 24 – has shed almost 10 stone. 
Currently a svelte size eight, she’s just bought her first scrubs set in size small. 
“It was really hard for me to work as a nurse and say to patients what they should be eating, when I was overweight myself,” Katie, from St Petersburg, Florida, USA, said. 
“I’d hear myself and think I should be doing that too, otherwise how can they take me seriously? 
“Now I’m like a different person in my scrubs. I feel confident and amazing, and feel like my patients are more interested in what I say.” Katie wearing a size 2X swimsuit in May 2015 in Florida (Photo: PA Real Life) Read More 
Katie had been overweight her whole life, despite playing volleyball and swimming as a teen. 
Looking back, she admitted her size was largely down to her poor diet. 
She’d eat biscuits for breakfast, fast food for lunch and macaroni cheese or fried chicken for dinner – as well as snacking on cookies throughout the day. 
“I was disgusted with the size of my stomach and I felt I had so many chins,” she said. 
“Clothes looked awful on me and I’d cry when I went shopping because nothing would fit.” 
Despite being self-conscious and unhappy with her rolls, Katie would justify her weight by telling herself her body was naturally meant to be bigger. 
But when she started working as a nurse, she realised how risky being big can be and decided to change. Katie, pictured here in March 2009, enjoyed tucking in to fast food for dinner, including fried chicken (Photo: PA Real Life) Read More 
She’d considered her weight loss surgery several times previously, but had never been brave enough to voice her idea until she confided in a colleague in May 2015 who assured her she’d benefit from it. 
“That conversation with my colleague kicked me into action,” she recalled. 
“I thought I could be happy looking in the mirror, rather than hating what I saw. 
“I knew if I didn’t make the appointment there and then, I’d chicken out.” 
So that’s what she did, and in September 2015 Katie had two-hour gastric sleeve surgery - an operation to remove part of the stomach restricting the amount that can be eaten - at Largo Medical Center, Florida. 
But Katie insists that, though the operation helped her shift the pounds, she still worked hard to get her trim figure. Read More 
She continued: “A lot of people think weight loss surgery is miraculous and that the weight just falls off, but you still have to eat healthy and exercise.” 
From there, Katie completely overhauled her diet, swapping fast food for fresh fruit and vegetables. 
On a typical day, she’d have egg and turkey bacon for breakfast, half a grilled chicken breast for lunch, a Caesar salad for dinner and peanut butter protein balls as snacks. 
She also started running three miles three or four days a week. 
In just a year, she lost 9st 2lb, and said she “felt on top of the world.” 
But her rapid transformation left her with folds of excess flesh, which began to chip away at her new found confidence. Read More 
She told of how she’d wear tight clothes that would “suffocate her abdomen” to cover it up. 
So, in January 2017 she underwent an abdominoplasty operation to remove her excess skin. 
She also had a breast lift at Bardmoor Surgery Centre, Florida. 
After that, she said she could finally look in the mirror and know what her body looked like. 
Katie, who documents her progress on Instagram @kburg21, said: “Now I catch myself staring at my reflection and I’m so amazed I can barely recognise my body. 
“For the first time I feel like people won’t judge my body, and I won’t either. I even tried on a bikini for the first time last week. 
“I think I’m a better nurse now and will walk into work confident in my new size small scrubs.” Like us on Facebook
